  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-203].
  {panel}

Scenario: 
There is an epic with several child stories in JIRA. Some of them have estimates, others are unestimated. 

In Portfolio, only the Epic is imported, which is sufficient to see the aggregated status/progress. 
However, displaying the ratio of unestimated items does not work in this case, as it only considers stories that are imported into Portfolio. 

expected: Take the same stories that are aggregated for the progress reporting and determine unestimated items based on issues without an original and remaining estimate on them.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-355].
  {panel}

See related task JPO-190 - 'calculate release' returns a start and end date in the past.

The workaround provided by Atlassian was to enter a current or future date in the 'Earliest Start' field, which I have been doing. (I still believe that it should not be necessary for the user to manually enter an appropriate start date to get around this system error.)

I have noticed that since upgrading to Portfolio 1.9.4, when I enter an earliest start date, the dynamic release start date typically returns a date the same as the earliest start date - there seems to be little or no correlation between the calculated release start date and the number of epics (with corresponding time estimates) prioritised higher than the epic in question.

Does the prioritisation of epics actually do anything?

Please help!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-315].
  {panel}

SYSTEM:

JIRA portfolio version: 1.9.2
JIRA version: 6.3.15

SCENARIO:
* Our "definition of done" is typical. Both implementation and testing must occur for a story to be complete. 
* Although there is some back-and-forth, the bulk of those two activities occur in two distinct, sequential stages.
* We want most stories to be completed in a single sprint.
* As suggested by "Understanding Stages and Skills" at https://confluence.atlassian.com/pages/viewpage.action?pageId=715262985, we are using stages for sequential activities. 

>"Typically, stages are used for activities that need to be done sequentially per work item."
>...
>"Another likely setup could be: 
>"* Design
>"* Implementation
>"* Test"

* In "Configure stages and skills," I've created two stages: "Development" and "QA."
* On the "People" page, I've created a team with two people, one checked for each stage. 
* On the "Backlog" page, I've created a single story, assigned to that team.
* To allow both stages to be scheduled within a single sprint, I've turned off the "stage/sprint constraints" in the plan configuration accessed via "Plan>Configure," on the page accessed with "Planning>Scheduling."
* I've configured the schedule views at the bottom so that "Grouping" is by "Members."
* I've examined the Epics, Stories and Capacity views.

EXPECTED:
* The QA stage will occur, and should be scheduled, after the development stage.

OBSERVED:
* The QA and development stages are displayed as concurrent, at least in the Epics, Stories and Capacity views.
fields.summary: Stages scheduled concurrently rather than sequentially

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-185].
  {panel}

I'm now using Portfolio to plan a cross-team delivery using a combination of Initiatives, Epics and Stories.  Epic estimates are being used for some and stories and their estimates for others. 

As all teams are following Scrum and story points I have created one stage (Delivery) with a skill for each team (i.e. iOS, Server, Android).

I'm having an issue where an Epic is not scheduled in what I perceive to be the correct sprint.  Our priority Epics are in one (blue) release and are estimated across several teams, but as the screenshot shows, on one team the Epic is not scheduled until Sprint 6-7.

I have checked all settings in the plan, set minimum load of story points to 0 (for epics) and even reduced the large Epic estimate (36) to a low number, and the Epic always remains "stuck" in Sprint 6.

Could you please advise the logic used for the Schedule and why this is happening?  I'm very close to getting complete business buy-in to use Portfolio for planning and finally abandoning all the spreadsheets, and this seems to be the final hurdle.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-389].
  {panel}

h2. Problem

The "Dependent story constraint" can be confusing, and it can result in JIRA Portfolio calculating impossible schedules.

h2. Suggestion

The feature should be documented and labeled better.  It appears to only apply to scrum teams but apparently it's relevant to any kind of team?

h2. Background

I'm planning a small milestone with a few tasks distributed between two teams.  Our hours-per-day setting is set to six hours.  In the attached image, you can see the time estimates.  There are four tasks (not stories, does it matter?) that depend on one another:

* Final QA (1 hour), depends on:
* QA fixes (4 hours), depends on:
* QA testing (2 hours), depends on:
* Mailer implementation (12 hours)

Those four issues form a critical path that will take at least 17 total hours.  JIRA Portfolio calculated a schedule that says that we should be able to accomplish all four of those things in one six-hour day.

That's impossible.

!Engineering_-_JIRA_Portfolio_-_JIRA.jpg|width=600px!
fields.summary: Calculated an impossible schedule

Steps to reproduce:

Additional comment - I've been reading the guide, these pages in particular:

https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAPortfolio/Regular+Plan+Updates
https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/JIRAPortfolio/Synchronization+Settings

...and it is very confusing! If you were able to simplify the whole estimate synchronisation functionality that would be great!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-471].
  {panel}

In a situation where a structured epic (i.e., one having child stories) and an unstructured work item (like a story or an epic without children) are linked to the same JIRA issue, the estimate suggestions in the _Update from date_ dialog are wrong. The children of the respective structure epic will end up receiving the overall  remaining estimate of the parent instead of the remaining estimates of the linked stories.

For instance, a situation like that:

||Portfolio work item||linked JIRA issue key||
|Epic 01|JIRA-01|
|  Child 1.01|JIRA-02|
|  Child 1.02|JIRA-03|
|Epic 02|JIRA-01|

This requires the plan to be use _Days_ or _Hours_ as planning unit, _Plan > Configure > Synchronization > Plan update > Update estimates_ to be turned on and a _time based_ progress configuration.
fields.summary: Replanning estimate suggestions don't work correctly if structured epic and an unstructured item are linked to the same JIRA issue

The JIRA log files will show an error similar to the following:
{code}/rest/roadmap/1.0/system/filters.json [jira.issue.search.OfBizSearchRequestStore] A JQL query exception was thrown parsing, error loading search request with id 'xxxxx' and name 'xxxxx' owned by 'xxxxx' query 'xxx xxx xxx xxx'.{code}

*Cause*
The query displayed above is incorrect/corrupt, and causes the import function to blow up.

*Resolution*
Find the saved filter in question based on id or filter name as displayed in the error. Remove it from the instance (GUI if possible, else directly in the database) or adjust it in order for it to become a valid filter.

Similar case: https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CONF-32634

  *NOTE:* This bug report is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding bug report|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-189].
  {panel}

Using Kanban team plan:

There have been a number of instances when the Report-Releases screen advises that some jobs cannot be done within the requested fixed period, at the same time that there are Free Capacities.  For example, a 14 hour job (comprised of 10 hours Back End Dev & 4 hours Technical Lead) displayed as a 14 hour overload (total amount of job) and being delivered after the fixed end date. At the same time, the card showed Free Capacities of Back End Dev, which doesn't make sense.

Atlassian suggested that rather than having separate stages for work type, eg, one stage for Design, another stage for Back End Dev, and another for Technical Lead etc, the calculation would probably work better if all work types were set up as different skills within one stage.  I have done this, but the problem described above still occurs.

Investigation into this issue would be greatly appreciated!

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1820].
  {panel}

h2. Problem Definition
JIRA has setup with components. Each component represent components in the enterprise systems.  When issue (story/task) is created first in JIRA first, during the initial analysis phase the component is assigned to the issue in JIRA.
Later during the planning phase, where PMO is creating a plan through Portfolio issues are imported on the portfolio plan. In the portfolio teams and skill sets are defined so that portfolio can suggest resource allocation. The component field is also visible on portfolio now. But currently there is no direct association between component and either team or skill sets. So when portfolio suggests resource allocation (or when PMO 'calculates' for the schedule) the resources picked up are from random teams - without any consideration on the skill set/teams. So the development tasks/stories will get QA or BA resource getting assigned.  The only option is to go individually on all the issues and change the resource allocation manually.  When there are 100 - 200 different epics (with average 5-10 tasks/stories under each epic)  under development for different releases, it becomes extremely tedious job. 


h2. Suggested Solution
I think we can have feature/option to link JIRA component with Portfolio skill set or project teams. 
One can associate/link component with teams created in portfolio. 
For example:
Component "Pricing engine" can be mapped to "Pricing team". Similarly component "XYZ adapter" can be mapped to "XYZ adapter team". 

For someone skills are more helpful to plan. In that case one can associate component with skills and this can be many to many relationship. 
For example:
Component "Pricing engine" can have multiple skill set associated with it.  Other component "XYZ adapter" may have other skill sets, but can share some skill set from "Pricing engine" component.

One can create this association while creating a plan from JIRA issues or from the "Configure" plan option.

Once the link between component and teams/skills is established, portfolio can use it while suggesting resource allocation on a schedule or calculating capacity.  Portfolio can now suggests resources which are at least meaningful (based on the teams/skill set).



Again, this link can be kept optional. so only those who require to use can use. Those who do not need it can continue with current behavior.
fields.summary: Link Project Components with Portfolio Skills.

fields.description:

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1364].
  {panel}

To be able to pick which specific fields should be updated to the respective JIRA issue when commited. Similar to the "Apply updates to project/s" options in standard plans.

h2. *Workaround*
*Don't commit releases as a whole*
This isn't the optimal solution but the best one we have for now.

* Create the planning release only in Portfolio
* When committing don't commit this entire category of changes (Filter the category using the dropdown in the commit dialog). 

Release assignment will remain pending as it does not exist in JIRA while other changes on that issue will apply.
fields.summary: Select specific fields to be updated in JIRA on commit - Live plans

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition:
Currently when an issue is excluded from a plan you can edit the issue sources under the plan settings *"Configure >> Issue Sources >> Edit Issue Sources" * then the items that were excluded will show up unselected, and you can manually review these items to get a list of issues or releases excluded from a plan this way and you can re-add those items to to the plan by reselecting them and submitting the changes.

However, there are no other ways to generate a list of issues or releases excluded from a plan.  If an issue or release is accidentally excluded there is no easy way to identify the item other than the method outlined above

h3. Suggested Solution
Provide a report in portfolio with a list of issues OR a JQL search option such as:
{code}
issue IN plan()
issue NOT IN plan()
issue Excluded from plan()
fixVersion IN plan()
fixVersion NOT IN plan()
fixVersion Excluded from plan()
{code}
Any option to generate a full list of items that are expressly excluded from a plan for easy identification
fields.summary: Option to create a list of issues excluded from plan
Lack of real progress

fields.description:
Actually only the EPICs from JIRA Software company managed projects are recognised and supported as EPICs by Portfolio.

Epics coming from the Team-managed (aka Next-Gen/Simplified/Independent/Agility) project's feature are not recognised as EPICs and are listed as "standard" tasks within the Portfolio plan's backlog without possibility to use them for dependancies.

*Workaround:*

Go to Portfolio's hierarchy configuration and map the Epic issue types coming from next-gen projects to the Epic level so Portfolio will properly recognise them.

STILL, once the mapping is done and the NextGen EPIC is mapped to the EPIC in the Portfolio's hierarchy settings:
 * The nextgen EPICs are recognised as EPIC and they can be created from within Portfolio and commit to the project, but there are other problems:
 ** The dependencies are not imported from the project source into portfolio
 ** The dependencies creation and updates are not commit from Portfolio to project. This is causing discrepancies between the project and the portfolio plan and then the project needs to be updated manually to fit the commit plan.
 ** The issues created with a dependency to an EPIC from Portfolio are not visible in the project backlog or board's views, they can be accessed as project's issues using the issuekey directly. This is not the case for the issues created without dependancy, they will appear in the project's backlog after the portfolio's plan change has been commit.
fields.summary: Add support for EPICs from Team Managed projects into Advanced Roadmaps

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1744].
  {panel}

*Problem statement*

For large projects, sprint and release dates are quite flexible and may not have a fixed duration length. e.g. for example, in a large organization (400-2000+ developer), the sprints could be by default 4 weeks length but have some exception during xmas period where the sprint is 1 week longer, as a lot of people are on vacation.

Portfolio 1.0 supports this feature with 'Custom Sprints', which allows us to configure a sprint with a length which differs from the default sprint length. However, Porfolio 2.0 does not support this out of box and this prevents any users using custom sprint to migrate from portfolio 1.x to 2.x

[https://answers.atlassian.com/questions/39440911/how-to-manage-variable-sprint-length-in-portfolio]

 

*Suggestion*

Support custom length sprints in portfolio 2.x
fields.summary: Support custom length sprints in portfolio 2.x
Gantt chart - Allow display of worked effort overlaying the estimated duration of a story/epic.

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Users can't remove the Team field  and it may cause confusion if they create another field with same name.

h3. Suggested Solution

fields.description:
As I user I would like to alocate a period of time of my developers daily availability to a specific task or issue on Portfolio.

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1620].
  {panel}

Relates to JPO-1532

Auto-scheduling of dependencies is done in such a way at the moment that it does not work for plans with more than one team/backlog who have dependencies between those backlogs. It only works reliably for dependencies _within_ the same backlog.

This is because a blocked item will be assigned a virtual rank below the item that is blocking it, and does not take dates into account in any way. This means that for teams with independent backlogs (and with no knowledge of the rank of the other team's issues) dependency scheduling can be very strange indeed (see JPO-1532).

A workaround for this is to disable the auto-scheduling of dependencies, but this removes one the of the most attractive features of Portfolio for JIRA.
A much better way, and more intuitive way, of scheduling dependencies is to do so based on the predicted end date/final sprint of the blocking item.
fields.summary: Auto-scheduling of dependencies based on date, not rank

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1045].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
For Kanban Teams, in an epic, there can be a possibility of the *Bottleneck* and *Free Capacities* is showing the same skill. This is caused by the bottleneck and free capacities are calculated on a daily basis and then aggregated weekly. 
 !Screen Shot 2015-11-18 at 10.38.00 am.png|thumbnail! 

*USE CASE*
* In this example, I have an epic that takes 4 days to complete
* I also only have 2 developers
* In the first day, both developers will work on the epic. This means 2 man-days of work will be done on that epic. This leaves 2-man days left
* However, for that first day, there will be a bottleneck as we did not have enough people to complete that epic in one day
* In the second day, both developers will again put in 2 man-days of work. This will complete the epic. So it will no longer be a bottle neck
* For the rest of the days of the week, there will be free capacities

{panel}
So if we list the bottlecks and capacities for the whole week it will look like:
Mon: Bottleneck
Tue: (No bottleneck or free capacity)
Wed: Free Capacity
Thu: Free Capacity
Fri: Free Capacity
When we aggregate/combine this for the whole week we get:
Week 1: Bottleneck and Free Capacity
{panel}

This could lead to confusion to the users

h3. Suggested Solution
* To show more details on the bottle neck & free capacity. Probably provide a 'Details' link beside the bottleneck and provide information on on which day is the bottleneck and free capacity falls.
fields.summary: Bottleneck and Free capacities showing the same skills

h5. Problem Definition
At the moment, when a user makes some changes in JIRA Portfolio plan and commits the changes, the value (for the same field) of that issue on JIRA's side (done by other colleagues) will be overwritten.

In the case where the user who makes the changes in JIRA Portfolio is not aware of the changes others make in JIRA's side, this will discard the changes and could mess up reports. At this moment, users are suggested to refresh the browser page before applying changes in JIRA Portfolio and commit right away. This will require users to refresh the page and commit changes often

h5. Suggested Solution
It would be great to have additional functionality in the commit feature to automatically check the last value entered (on JIRA's side) to be applied in Portfolio and adjust it accordingly in JIRA Portfolio before applying this changes back to JIRA's side.
fields.summary: Having a check on the last changes made in JIRA before JIRA Portfolio performs a commit

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1822].
  {panel}

Hi there,

we are struggling a bit with Portfolio with managing external dependencies. Let me give you an example.

We have an Epic (e.g. New website), this includes a lot of tasks that are completely under our control (prepare texts, code HTML template) but also contains some tasks that are managed outside our team (e.g. check legal with lawyers, get design from external freelancer). 

The problem here is that we know how long this typically takes (e.g. lawyer check = 2-3 weeks, UX design 2-3 weeks), but we are struggling with modeling this in a Portfolio plan.

Here are some hacks we tried and got almost there.
 # Created an External team with Lawyer & Designer virtual team members.
 # Added 3 skills (Core, Legal, Design) with 100%, 0%, 0% default setup.
 # Setup our internal team for Core skill and External team (Laywer = Legal, Designer = Design)

This works pretty well.
 # Portfolio will not try to recalculate plan and assign tasks to External team if you dont explicitly estimate some work for Legal/Design skill.
 # You can make an upper limit capacity for your external suppliers (handy since you don't want to overload them when you need them on multiple projects simultaneously.

However. There is one minor glitch. If you actually don't care about capacity of the third party or you don't want to create a team member for every external supplier you are stuck.

*Suggestion:*

How about adding a special wait time estimate to tasks? You just say - this task will take about 20hours from an external source (skill) and i dont care about capacity planning. Everything else will just work as is.

Is there any other better way to model this in Portfolio?
fields.summary: Better support for managing external dependencies

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1349].
  {panel}

As a user I would like to have possibility to make simulation of future sprints in two modes:
a) Planning based on capacity (current approach)
b) Planning based on story order

Here’s the example:

Let’s say that we have following backlog for some team:
- Story1 (10 points)
- Story2 (5 points)
- Story3 (8 points)
- Story4 (2 points)

Velocity of the team is 20 points.

In mode a) planning fills the sprints with stories until reaching team velocity. So it looks like that:

Planning of sprint 1:
- Story1 goes into sprint (10 / 20 points used)
- Story2 goes into sprint (15 / 20 points used)
- Story3 is too big
- Story4 goes into sprints (17 / 20 points used)

Planning of sprint 2:
- Story3 goes into sprint (8 / 20 points used)

What happened? Order of stories in sprints is different than order in the backlog. In real world sometimes it’s possible, but sometimes it has no sense. There could be situation where we have some dependencies – Story4 cannot be implemented before Story3.

In mode b) planning fills the sprints without changing their order. So it goes like that:

Planning of sprint 1:
- Story1 goes into sprint (10 / 20 points used)
- Story2 goes into sprint (15 / 20 points used)
- Story3 is too big – algorithm finishes planning here

Planning of sprint 2:
- Story3 goes into sprint (8 / 20 points used)
- Story4 goes into sprints (10 / 20 points used)
fields.summary: Live Plan - planning stories according to their order

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1785].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition
Live plans will be listed on "View All Plans" page and can be viewed by all users that have Portfolio USER or VIEWER permission.

h3. Suggested Solution
Have a way to set Plan-level permission during Plan creation wizard with options to have Plan permission required

h3. Why this is important
A user can use any names as Live plan names and this _can_ breach data privacy and legal issue in a multi-tenant instance. Hiding it early during creation is important for this setup.
fields.summary: Allow setting of plan-level permission during Plan creation wizard

fields.description:
{panel:bgColor=#e7f4fa}
  *NOTE:* This suggestion is for *JIRA Portfolio Cloud*. Using *JIRA Portfolio Server*? [See the corresponding suggestion|http://jira.atlassian.com/browse/JPOSERVER-1717].
  {panel}

h3. Problem Definition

In a portfolio plan, stories are shown nested underneath their parent Epics. When a story is completed and marked as done (and a Resolution is set within JIRA), the story disappears off the plan. 

Users would like the ability to customize or otherwise configure Portfolio so that such completed/resolved stories still remain visible on the board until the entire parent Epic is complete. This is in order to keep the scope of the entire Epic's stories in context.

h3. Suggested Solution

Allow for either a Portfolio administration option, or an additional filter option from within Portfolio's planning view, to allow for completed issues with resolution set to still be visible on the plan.

h3. Workaround 
None
fields.summary: Allow for closed/resolved stories to still be shown on plan when parent Epic is still incomplete

I am using Portfolio to plan multiple projects that are being worked on in Jira Agile.

I use Initiatives for Projects and import Epics and child issues as they are set up in the Jira Agile project.

The act of importing epics and issues into Portfolio is rather cumbersome without being able to bulk assign, so I don't want to be doing this regularly.

However, from time to time, child issues get moved from one epic to another in Jira Agile. 

I've to find a report in Jira Agile that identifies when issues move to another epic but this doesn't seem possible.  

Is there a way that Portfolio can pick this up?
